description: From Middle English seven-night, sevenight, sevenyght [and other forms], from Late Old English seofeniht, seoueniht (compare seofonnihte (“seven days old; seven days long”, adjective)), from seofon (“seven”) (ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *septḿ̥ (“seven”)) + niht (“night; day (when computing spans of time)”) (ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *nókʷts (“night”)). Doublet of sennight.

entries.meaning: A period of seven consecutive days and nights; a week.
examples: Synonyms: (archaic or obsolete) sennight, (Britain, dialectal) zennet

entries.meaning: (attributively) Preceded by a specified day such as Sunday, today, or yesterday: a week from the specified day.
Preceded by a specified day and come: a week after the specified day.
Preceded by a specified day and gone or was: a week before the specified day.
